subject: Art
title: Rule of Thirds in Photos
description: Placing subjects off-center for naturally engaging photographs.

hook.text: Turn on the grid overlay on your phone camera. Those two horizontal and two vertical lines divide the frame into nine sections. Place your subject at any intersection and your photo instantly improves.

buildup.text: Horizon on the top third = more foreground. Horizon on the bottom third = more sky. Subject at a side intersection = natural feel with space to look into. Subject dead center = static and formal.

discovery.text: The rule works because off-center placement creates visual tension ‚Äî the viewer's eye moves between the subject and the surrounding space. It turns a snapshot into a composition.

twist.text: The rule is a training wheel, not a commandment. As you develop your eye, you'll find compositions that work at center, at extreme edges, or that defy any grid. The rule gets you started; instinct takes you further.

climax.text: Take the same scene: shoot it with the subject centered, then at each of the four intersection points. Compare all five. The centered shot will feel different ‚Äî not always worse, but definitely more static.

punchline.text: When in doubt, put the subject on a third. It's the simplest upgrade from snapshot to photograph.

quiz.question: Why does placing a subject off-center often create a stronger photograph?
options: It creates visual tension that engages the viewer as their eye moves between subject and space
It makes the camera focus better
